bibl.note: This is a letter dated September 17, 1807 from P. Perkins to his cousin Peter Hardeman in Franklin, Tennessee. In the letter, Perkins tells Hardeman of a fever that he and many people in his area are suffering from. Also in the letter, he asks Hardeman to join him on a northern speculation trip for slaves.

div1.p:
I have but little to say to you present times dull and if is very sickly perhaps thesickelyest season the inhabitants have experienced for some years we have had our own experience of the season hear it has been not uncommon for seven & eight at a time down with the fever god knows I had it seventeen days pretty high but by the aid of three physicians I have had the good fortune to save my life so far but am not yet well, telo cousin John Hardeman that I have recd 7 dollars form Benj. Stephens for him and recd to him for that amt. stephens says that he thinks that the whole he owes I expect I shall set out with Mrs. Perkins for Tennessee on or about the first of november I shall set out for Tornbechee in a few days and as soon as I return I set out if I can get money enough I shall
endeavour to go northwardly on some speculation or other either buying negroes or merchandise tho I rather expect the former I would be very glad we could go to gether__ but stop I have not the money yet__ I will say more when I get it__ my best wishes to uncle Hardeman tell him I have that child his grand Daughter a thing unexpected no doubt__ Mr Bennit wishes you to find out whether his wife is in the state or not and if convenient get the Testimony of some person to that effect__ I think they never will live to gether again if so they had better both have a divorce he says he never will be done serving you if you do it but you can Judge of the matter best Mrs. Perkins joins me in love to you
div1.closer:
I m Dr Sir yours with every attention P. Perkins
NATCHEZ*Sep-22 Mr Peter Hardeman
Franklin
Tennessee mail 25
